turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Robert, I think you better just...

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: You're all full of shit!

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Come on, get moving, dammit!!

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Will you shut up for a minute!!  Pull your car out of line.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Haven't you got a jacket or anything with you?

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: No, I don't, I uh... it got burned up. Everything in the car got the shit burned out of it. All I got left is what I have on...

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: I've got an extra jacket behind the seat, if you want to put it on.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: No, it's okay.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Suit yourself. But I'll tell you, where we're headed is gonna get colder'n hell.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: It's all right. I'm fine.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: You've been staying in a motel all this time?

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: For two whole weeks, an' there wasn't hardly nobody there to talk to but me. The manager of the place told me it was the off season, an' it must a ben, because other'n me, there was just this 25-year-old kid, DeLyon, that didn't appear to be all there, an' this old married pair next to me that was always hollerin' for quiet. Can you imagine? All you could a heard there was a pin, an' them, hollerin' away...

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: I don't understand why you had to stay in a motel. There's more than enough room here.

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: Well, I was goin' to, but Bobby said he hadda kind of feel things up here first, which I can understand, but then it went an' took so long, I ran flat outa money...  I didn't have no number to call, you know.  So I hadda clear outa there an' come on up here, in the hopes that I wouldn't be intrudin' myself...

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Oh, no. You're more than welcome.

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: Well, thank you, that's a very nice thing for you to say.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Not at all.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: No, you're not. Go ahead and take your time.

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: I do eat slow as a bird, whereas Bobby can put it away like a speed swing...  Is there any ketchup around?

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: What kind of doggy is that?

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: It's a Borzoi.

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: Oh, uh huh. I had a little kittycat once, that Bobby give me...

turns.speaker: TITA
turns.text: Oh no, it's been much more than that.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Away from the piano, Tita, you have no sense of time at all.

turns.speaker: TITA
turns.text: I don't think that's true.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: It is true.

turns.speaker: TITA
turns.text: Besides being very rude.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: You know, just after I came back off tour with the Betenthaller Quartet, Dad, myself and Herbert had a summit conference about you...

turns.speaker: TITA
turns.text: Oh, my, "a summit conference." I wonder where I was, polishing silver behind the coal bin.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: I don't know where you were, penis envy.

turns.speaker: TITA
turns.text: I hope I didn't hear that.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: At any rate, Dad wanted to hire a private detective to ferret you out, and I said, "What for?" Whatever the hell he's doing, even if it's a completely wasteful escapade, it's entirely his business. Simple as that...

turns.speaker: TITA
turns.text: What's wrong, Carl, you hardly ate anything...

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: I took some aspirin and it really upset my stomach.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: And what about love?

turns.speaker: SAMIA
turns.text: What about it? Wouldn't you agree that a great deal of mischief has been done in the name of love?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: No, I wouldn't.

turns.speaker: SAMIA
turns.text: Well, you're a romantic, Catherine, as are most musicians, and what's more, about to be married...

turns.speaker: SAMIA
turns.text: ... which should exclude you from any objective discussion. But keep in mind, even the arts aren't free of aggressive content, nor the institution of marriage.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I think these cold, "objective" discussions are aggressive, Samia...

turns.speaker: SAMIA
turns.text: But I'd like to say, so that I don't dampen the spirit of your adventure...

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You haven't dampened my spirit, Samia... Excuse me.

turns.speaker: SAMIA
turns.text: Well, I should hope not...

turns.speaker: PALM
turns.text: Come on, Terry, we got a ride!

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: Jesus, what a rude person...

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: There'd never be a hole big enough. Now took at me, for instance, when I was just one person, before Bobby, I had so much garbage collectin' onto me every day, I was thinkin' about gettin a dispose all...

turns.speaker: PALM
turns.text: A dispose-all, what's that but more crap? I've never seen such crap. Oofh, I don't know how people get up in the morning.

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: PALM
turns.text: Not dirt. See, dirt isn't bad. It's filth. Filth is bad. That's what starts maggots and riots...

turns.speaker: PALM
turns.text: Hey, follow that truck. They know the best places to stop.

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: That's an old maid's tale.

turns.speaker: PALM
turns.text: Bullshit! Truck drivers know the best eating places on the road.

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: Salesmen and cops are the ones. If you'd ever waitressed, honey, you'd know.

turns.speaker: PALM
turns.text: Don't call me "honey," mack.

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: Don't call me "mack," honey.

turns.speaker: PALM
turns.text: I wouldn't be a waitress. They're nasty and full of crap.

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: You better hold onto your tongue!

turns.speaker: PALM
turns.text: Hold onto this.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Mass production is what does it.

turns.speaker: PALM
turns.text: What do you mean "mass"... I have to come out and tell you, you're not that clean, either.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Wait a minute. I'm not that neat, maybe, but I am clean.

turns.speaker: PALM
turns.text: Well, you're not that bad, but some people... I mean, people's homes, just filth. I've been in people's homes...

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: In my personal observation, I think that more people are neat than are clean...

turns.speaker: PALM
turns.text: In my personal thing, I don't see that. I'm seeing more filth. A lot of filth. What they need to do every day, no, once in a while, is a cockroach thing, where they spray the homes. And uh... can you imagine, if their doors were painted a pretty color, and they had a pot outside, with...

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Yeah, it could be adorable...

turns.speaker: PALM
turns.text: And they picked up! I mean, it wouldn't be filthy, with Coke bottles and whiskey, and those signs everywhere...

turns.speaker: PALM
turns.text: And you know, I read where they invented this car that runs on... that runs on... when you boil water...

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Steam.

turns.speaker: PALM
turns.text: Right, steam. A car you could ride around in and not cause a stink. But do you know, they will not even let us have it. Can you believe it? Why?! Man! He likes to create a stink. I wrote them a note once, and told them to clean it... I mean, don't you see that? It's just filthy! I mean, I've seen filth you wouldn't believe! Oofh, what a stink! I don't even want to talk about it...

turns.speaker: SAMIA
turns.text: John believes in the basic goodness of man, and that's fine, but gaze into the pit like I have and that view seems a little soporific. And not unlike television, it hardly represents the real world...

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: There's some good things on it, though.

turns.speaker: SAMIA
turns.text: Pardon me?

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: The TV. There's some good things on it, sometimes.

turns.speaker: SAMIA
turns.text: I strongly doubt it, but I wasn't really discussing media...

turns.speaker: SAMIA
turns.text: The choice of words, "squashed flat," juxtaposed against the image of a fluffy kitten...

turns.speaker: RAYETTE
turns.text: Well, she was.

turns.speaker: SAMIA
turns.text: Perhaps...

turns.speaker: SECOND ENGINEER
turns.text: Miss Dupea.

turns.speaker: TITA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SECOND ENGINEER
turns.text: I'd like to remind you again, this isn't an opera or a musical comedy.

turns.speaker: TITA
turns.text: Oh... I'm sorry. Was I singing again?

turns.speaker: SECOND ENGINEER
turns.text: If you want to call it that.

turns.speaker: TITA
turns.text: Well, you have to simply tell me, that's all.

turns.speaker: SECOND ENGINEER
turns.text: That's exactly what I am doing, again.

turns.speaker: TITA
turns.text: Do you have to let me get halfway through the movement first? This is tiring me.

turns.speaker: SECOND ENGINEER
turns.text: I have a suggestion. Why don't we take a break.

turns.speaker: TITA
turns.text: Oh, for pity's sake...

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Don't fuck wit' me! Don't fuck wit' me.  My lawyer's so good he'll have you workin in Alaska, so dress warn.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Aaron, how you doin'?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Look at me.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Why you have an attitude for?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Not now, I'm busy

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: God, I just wanna speak to you. I just wanna speak to you the way I feel about you.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Hurry up, you're wastin' my time, what the fuck.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Please don't scream at me. I like you, but I don't like the way your attitude is.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: So get the fuck outta here.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: I wanna go out with you, I want to be part of your life. I want you to treat me the way a girlfriend should be treated.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Then don't go out with me.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: For once in your life have some 	respect for me, don't even curse at me or nothin'.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Now she's tellin' me what the fuck to do.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: God, you drive me crazy. I just want you to know how I feel and you don't understand.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Just get the fuck outta here.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Alright, tell me, what'd you hear?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: There's a rumor that you were tryin' to get somebody to beat me up.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: What chu listening to rumors for? I'm not like dat.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Is it true?

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: I told you, no. I'm not that type.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Then I want you to go to whoever's sayin' that and tell them to stop.

turns.speaker: AARON
turns.text: Alright.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I'm wit' Carlos.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: Do you have a name?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Victor.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Victor.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: Wussup?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Wussup.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Yo.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Remember me, from the pool?

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: Um. Yeah! Shorty!

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: So watcha doin'?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Nothin'.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: What are you doin' here?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I, umm, came to see you.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: You know somebody around here?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: No.  What you do today?

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: Oh you know, cleaned the house, cooked. Took care of my little sisters. Sit down. So where's Carlos?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I guess he's outside someplace I don't like takin' him down to certain places.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: Whadja wanna see me about?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I just wanted to see you.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: So you got a girl?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: So what's her name?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: You know. I got a lot, more than one.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: A play-ya.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: You got a boyfriend?

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: Me? No. Don't want none either. Such bastards, man.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: So wadda you do with your girls?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Just chill.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: That's it?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Nah, we make out and stuff.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: So what you think of me?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: You look good.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: I look good, that's it. So what else do you do for these girls?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I buy them flowers.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: How you treat them?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Good. I'm faithful to them.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: See, I got you, you are so scared. I don't believe that you kissed no girls. That you got three girls and that you faithful and this and that.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I did.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: Well, you know I'm standin' here and you say I look good?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I kissed those girls.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: No you didn't, you ain't provin'it.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I aint gotta prove nothin' to no girl, 'cause I got it like dat.

turns.speaker: AMANDA
turns.text: Oh, 'cause you got it like dat?

turns.speaker: CARL0S
turns.text: Come down!

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I can't!

turns.speaker: CARL0S
turns.text: Who gives!

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I can't, I'm gonna get punished more!

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Wussup?

turns.speaker: CARL0S
turns.text: Wussup, Victor.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Yo, can I talk to you for a minute?

turns.speaker: CARL0S
turns.text: Eddie from Compost?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Eddie from Baruch, the one who was sittin' wit' dat little girl;

turns.speaker: CARL0S
turns.text: Why don't you ask Eddie?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Yo, Carlos-I'm gonna punch you.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I got punished, man.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Fa what?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I won't let my motha cut my hair.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Wha'?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: She fucks it all up!

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Forget it! C'mon Let's go to the pool.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I can't man, I'm punished!

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: They are?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Yeah! Tell me which one you would like. To be doin' nothin on a fire escape or beat the pool with a bunch of girls? Be straight up!

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I'll be right down.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: So what girls are over there?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Natasha, Maria, Tina-

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: These are the pretty girls you told me to come down for?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: What are you going that way for?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: I'm not goin' to 10th Street, people piss and shit in that pool,

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Where you goin'?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Pitt.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Oh man, what we gotta leave ar' own neighborhood for?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: C'mon.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Man, if I go down you're goin' down with me.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Amanda is Eddie's cousin.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Eddie from Compost?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: No, Baruch.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I gotta go take a piss.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: If we were at 10th Street Pool you woulda done it right in the water, right?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Yo, remember from the pool, that girl?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Which one?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: You know, Eddie's cousin.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: The one with the phat ass?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: No, c'mon, stop playin'. The girl that you kissed when we got there. Where s he live at?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: I'm gonna punch you. What you want with her anyway? You in love with her?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: She lives near Eddie?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: I think she lives down by Pitt.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Near Natasha's? Or over by Boy's Club?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: I think by Twenty-two.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: For real?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: What you want with her anyway'

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Yo! What you goin' for

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: 'Cause you know what, you're not supposed to know but yesterday she lent me her pills for her Moms and if I don't give 'em to her she's gonna die. You want her to die?

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: How does he look up close?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Umm, he got dark brownish eyes, he got a nice nose I love his nose. I love his skin. I love his lips, he got a great smile and he got-

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: A bad attitude.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Yeah, he got a bad attitude.

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: You said before, that he got boxes?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Yeah, he got boxes in his stomach. He's taller than me.

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: How old is he?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: I think he's 18 or 17.

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: You gonna talk to him?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Um, yeah I think so.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Like this?

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: Yeah, that's right, you got it girl.

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: Now salsa, you know how to dance salsa?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MICHELLE
turns.text: Okay, then dance. Show.

turns.speaker: HECTOR
turns.text: You looking for somebody?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Wha'?

turns.speaker: HECTOR
turns.text: You here to see somebody?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: HECTOR
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: A girl named Amanda.

turns.speaker: HECTOR
turns.text: What she look like?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: She's like this high, dark hair, skinny

turns.speaker: HECTOR
turns.text: Yo, that's my girl.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: She didn't say she had no man.

turns.speaker: HECTOR
turns.text: I suggest you turn around and go back to where you came from.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: You sure? She's got kind of like brown hair.

turns.speaker: JENETTE
turns.text: Positive.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: You sure?

turns.speaker: JENETTE
turns.text: Positive.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: My friend told me she lived around here.

turns.speaker: JENETTE
turns.text: Your friend must be misinformed.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Didn't I see you at Pitt yesterday?

turns.speaker: JENETTE
turns.text: So what do you want with her anyway?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: I'm a good friend of hers.

turns.speaker: JENETTE
turns.text: How do I know you're not lying.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Yo, I know what you're thinking, that I'm one of those guys that keep coming up to her.

turns.speaker: JENETTE
turns.text: Probably.  One of the many.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JENETTE
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JENETTE
turns.text: So, then whadda ya want?

turns.speaker: JENETTE
turns.text: You wanna do somethin' with me?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Not really.

turns.speaker: JENETTE
turns.text: Hey!

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Wha'?

turns.speaker: JENETTE
turns.text: Where you know Amanda from?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Jus' from around the way.

turns.speaker: JENETTE
turns.text: You live around here?

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JENETTE
turns.text: You gotta girLfrLend?

turns.speaker: JENETTE
turns.text: I know how ta get him back if you want.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Nah.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: First of all, let me just reiterate that this is not a formal investigation. I'm not going through formal channels here, because if Alan Stanwyk is not involved in any improprieties, then nobody has to know I was even --

turns.speaker: BOYD
turns.text: Alan Stanwyk is not involved in improprieties. Where the hell does the S.E.C. come off --

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Look. You know that and I know that, but somebody's bucking for a promotion. I think it's that bozo, Hanrahan, I can't be sure. Anyway, unless I go back there with something, you and your son-in-law are next week's scapegoats.

turns.speaker: BOYD
turns.text: Unbelievable.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I feel like dirt. They even want to know what he's doing in Utah?

turns.speaker: BOYD
turns.text: Utah?  Jesus Christ! First of all, Alan Stanwyk does not own one share of stock.The three million dollars for the ranch in Provo comes from my daughter who converted some of her personal holdings, not company holdings. Now if anybody in DC wants to make something of that, bring 'em on. Until then, get the hell out of my face.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: God I admire you.

turns.speaker: BOYD
turns.text: By the way: what kind of name is Poon?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Comanche Indian.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Yes sir, you are confirmed on Flight 306 to Rio tomorrow evening at 11 PM. First Class.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: You're kidding.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Would you like me to change anything?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: So he's going. Uh... are there any other tickets charged to the same account?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: We'd have no way of knowing that, sir.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Hmm. It's just that there are some other people from my office going on this trip and... is there anyone in the seat next to me?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Never heard of him. Thanks anyway.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: You mean her.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Sally Ann Cavanaugh. Oh wait, she couldn't work in your office, she's not from around here.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Oh, thanks.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Maybe tonight?

turns.speaker: CREASY
turns.text: Whaddyamean 'maybe'?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: That's what he said.

turns.speaker: CREASY
turns.text: He doesn't know? How come he doesn't know?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I don't know how he doesn't know. He doesn't know.

turns.speaker: CREASY
turns.text: Sonofabitch.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Wonder who his supplier is.

turns.speaker: CREASY
turns.text: I have no idea.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I wasn't asking.

turns.speaker: CREASY
turns.text: He never leaves the beach, Fat Sam. Never leaves. Sits in that chair, he's outta junk. Then he suddenly gets up, he's got junk. So where does it come from? Through the sand?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I think that's highly unlikely, Creasy.

turns.speaker: CREASY
turns.text: I ought to get some sleep.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Creasy, how old are you?

turns.speaker: CREASY
turns.text: Nineteen.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: You're not taking real good care of yourself.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Hey, what are you doing?

turns.speaker: CREASY
turns.text: Fletch, this is dumb.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: You don't have to run with me, Crease.

turns.speaker: CREASY
turns.text: Fletch!

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: What goddamn right do you have to take him?

turns.speaker: CREASY
turns.text: Hey you're really nuts.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: They didn't do anything.

turns.speaker: CREASY
turns.text: What? What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I busted their window, they didn't do anything.

turns.speaker: CREASY
turns.text: You're lucky.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Not luck. They don't want me.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: You decorate this yourself or did Mrs. Chief of Police help you?

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: You should have seen what she wanted to do with the place. Mauve.  So what's your name?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Fletch.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: Full name.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Fletch F. Fletch

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: I see. And what do you do for a living, Mr. Fletch?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I'm President of the International Fletch Corporation.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: Why are you doing this Mr. Fletch?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Frankly sir, you look a little like my father. Probably explains the curious feeling of love I have for you.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: For a gentleman who was just found holding a bag full of heroin...

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: It was planted on me, sir.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: We're looking at five years, maybe ten. Is that what you want... Jane Doe?

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: Your editor called me yesterday to respond to allegations you're about to print about police involvement in narcotics dealing. Fletch starts to get up, but Cummings plants his foot on Fletch's chest, forces him back down.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: I'm about to break that beach wide open, and I don't need some pennyante Woodward and Bernstein getting in the way of my men.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: 'Your men' might just be involved in all this.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: You idiot. Off the record, deep background: I've got that beach crawling with undercover cops.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: You go back to that goddamn beach, I swear to God I'll make you regret it.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Hey, you and Tommy Lasorda. That's great.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: You can't keep me here.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: Maybe I'm not going to keep you here.  Maybe I'm gonna blow your brains out.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I'm no lawyer, but I do believe that's a violation of my rights.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: After I shoot you, I stick the knife in my arm, then place it in your dead hand. Self-defense. We don't do this very much anymore... but we have. Got rid of a lot of minorities that way.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: My God, you're serious.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: Ask anybody.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Can I ask anybody now?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Can I call my Mom? I'd like to tell here how much I've always loved her.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: What'll it be Fletch?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I hate the beach. Wouldn't go there if you paid me. Besides, I'm way overdue on my story about off-track betting in the Himalayas. You don't think it's the mafia, do you?

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: Its been very nice meeting you. I enjoy your column.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: Speaking of which, you're not going to print anything before my investigation is through, are you?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Not a prayer.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: That a boy.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: Thanks for coming down to see us.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Not at all, Chief. But next time... no tongue, okay?

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: Greetings, everyone.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Thank God, the police.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: This one's going to be even more fun.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Go ahead. Make my evening.

turns.speaker: MR. STANWYK
turns.text: What the hell are you doing here?

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: Put the gun down, Alan. I'll take care of them.

turns.speaker: MR. STANWYK
turns.text: I've got it all under control, Jerry. You can go now.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: Under control? You idiot. You didn't know who he was?

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: Fat Sam left the beach today. So did Gummy. It began to occur to me that some things are beginning to happen that maybe I should be aware of.

turns.speaker: MR. STANWYK
turns.text: I said I'll take care of it. Now, a man of your position shouldn't be a part of what's about to go down. So go home and I'll call you tomorrow.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: What, 'long distance?' I couldn't help but hear you say something about Rio, Alan. You're not leaving with the eight hundred thousand dollars I staked you for the next load, are you?

turns.speaker: MR. STANWYK
turns.text: Jerry, you're simply going to have to trust me. I've got a foolproof way to get rid of this guy and now you're jeopardizing everything.

turns.speaker: CUMMINGS
turns.text: Your 'foolproof' way is going to land my ass on the front page while you're basking in Rio.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: So where do you know Alan from?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: We play tennis at the club.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Really. The California Racquet Club?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: That's my club too. I haven't seen you there.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Well, I haven't played in a while because of these kidney pains.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Right, and how long have you had these pains, Mr. Barber?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: That's Babar.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Two bs?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: One. B-a-b-a-r.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: That's two.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: But not right next to each other. I thought that's what you meant.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Arnold Babar. Isn't there a children's book about an elephant named Babar?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I don't know. I don't have any.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: No children?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: No books. No elephants either. No really good elephant books.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Still, it'd an odd name. I don't remember seeing it on the club registry.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Oh, I don't belong formally. I've gone with my aunt.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Your aunt?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Mrs. Smith.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Joan or Margaret Smith.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Well, which one?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Margaret.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Funny old bird.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Is she ever. I've got some stories....

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: I'll bet. Shame about Ed.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: It was. Really a shame. To go so suddenly.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Oh, he was dying for years.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Sure, but the end was so sudden.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: He was in intensive care for eight weeks.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Yes, but the very end, when he actually died, that was extremely sudden.  You know, Alan and I were recently speaking of dying. Told me Boyd Aviation took out a lot of insurance on him. You must have to be in some kind of perfect health to get that kind of policy.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Bend over and drop your pants, Mr. Babar.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Oh really, there's no need to -- we don't want to do that...

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Just relax....

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Honest, I feel fine. You better be married.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Did I say 'kidneys'? I meant my ear. Maybe I should see an ear dahhh --  Ever serve time?

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Breathe easy...

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Anyway, I'm surprised Alan got the policy so easily. I know there's a history of cancer in the family.

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: There is?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Whoa, look out there. You really need the whole fist?

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Just relax.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Gee, Alan's been looking kind of sick lately. Is he all right?

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: I can't discuss another patient. You know that.  Well, I can't find anything wrong with you.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I'm sure it's not for a lack of looking. Maybe I should get a real complete physical. You give Alan an annual, don't you?

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Yeah, we check you into Mt. Hebron for a few days, run lots of tests, charge a bundle. You can pull your pants up now.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I hope they still fit. Do I get to keep the glove?

turns.speaker: DR. DOLEN
turns.text: Tell the nurse when you've got a few free days. She'll make all the arrangements.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Thanks, Doc. Maybe I'll come back with a date. Or an elephant.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: So what do you figure?

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: No idea.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: No idea at all?

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: Okay. Some idea.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Like when?

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: Like tonight.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: For sure?

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: No, not for sure. When it comes, it comes. You gonna want some shit?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I think Id rather have drugs.

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: Fletch...

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Sorry. I find a little humor really brightens things up around here, dont you?

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: Jesus.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: You don't know me.

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: My pleasure.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I'm serious, Sam.

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: What, the heat here?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Affirmative.

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: The two surfer boys?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Affirmative.

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: Thought so. What for?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: For me. I'm a reporter, Sam. I'm breaking the drug story and I got the chief red-handed. Gummy gave me a deposition.

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: You gonna nail the chief?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I'm gonna nail the chief. And you can help or --

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: Oh, I'll help, Fletch. I'm a slave to that sonofabitch. He busted me, third offense, gave me a choice: Work for him or do fifteen long. All I get out of this is free snort.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: You don't have a piece of the action?

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: Noooo. Free snort. That's it.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Wait five minutes, and go to my office. You'll get federal protection after that.

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: Gonna need it. That boy is dangerous. Fletch?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: You find the source?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Gum thought Brazil.

turns.speaker: FAT SAM
turns.text: Rio. Know how he gets it in the country? Some big shot airline executive flies it in on company jets. Very impressive operation, Fletch. Very impressive.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: It's me doctor Rosenpenis. I just have to take another peek at Alan Stanwyk's file. What have they done with this place?

turns.speaker: RECORDS NURSE
turns.text: Nothing. They're still there.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Right. Fine.

turns.speaker: RECORDS NURSE
turns.text: Are you all right, Doctor?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Where am I?

turns.speaker: RECORDS NURSE
turns.text: You're in the Records Room.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I'm fine.

turns.speaker: RECORDS NURSE
turns.text: Can I get you something?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Have you got a make-shift plywood pillory? Heh Heh, just kidding.

turns.speaker: RECORDS NURSE
turns.text: Doctor Holmes went to get you some smelling salts. He was quite surprised that you fainted.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Well, I didn't want to say anything, but I thought the dead man was my brother.

turns.speaker: RECORDS NURSE
turns.text: Oh my God!

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: It's all right. It wasn't him but that spleen was a splitting image.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Oh, God, I think I'm about to hyperventilate. Have you got a paper bag, or something.

turns.speaker: RECORDS NURSE
turns.text: Yes, right away.

turns.speaker: RECORDS NURSE
turns.text: Here you are, Doctor.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: RECORDS NURSE
turns.text: Is there anything particular you're looking for?

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: My associates did a biopsy on this man recently.  He's supposed to have a melanoma, or a carcinoma, some kind of noma. Hmmm. I can't seem to find any record of it.

turns.speaker: RECORDS NURSE
turns.text: Well, if he had one, it would certainly be in here.  Wait. Here it is. Yep. Surgical removal of two moles. Tissue was benign.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: That's it?

turns.speaker: RECORDS NURSE
turns.text: That's it.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: This was last month. So Alan Stanwyk does not have cancer.

turns.speaker: RECORDS NURSE
turns.text: I guess not.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: He'll be so relieved.

turns.speaker: GILLETT
turns.text: Refusal to pay alimony is a jailable offense, Fletch.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: What about breaking and entering?  Are you wearing anything under that?

turns.speaker: GILLETT
turns.text: I did not break nor enter. I simply chose an advisable location to await my client's delinquent husband.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: I hate to conduct business on the lanai. Why don't we step inside.

turns.speaker: GILLETT
turns.text: You owe Wendy nine hundred and eighteen dollars.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: She doesn't need the money, for crissakes. She's living with Monty. I know it.

turns.speaker: GILLETT
turns.text: I don't know what you're referring to. Wendy maintains her own residence.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: It stinks. I thought woman were independent now.

turns.speaker: GILLETT
turns.text: Until she remarries, Fletch.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: Hey, shut up, okay? I just hate this.

turns.speaker: GILLETT
turns.text: I empathize with your plight, Fletch. However, you threw her out.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: She was sleeping with everybody. The cable TV guy. You can't get lower than that...

turns.speaker: GILLETT
turns.text: You should have proved that in a court of law.

turns.speaker: FLETCH
turns.text: My lawyer was a bum.

turns.speaker: GILLETT
turns.text: I agree.
